feed.title: Changing the Guard
feed.station: Victoria, Green Park, St Jamess Park or Hyde Park Corner
feed.description:
Changing the Guard at Buckingham Palace encompasses colourful spectacle and British pageantry. During the Changing the Guard ceremony, also known as Guard Mounting, one regiment takes over from another. The Queens Guard is made up of the St Jamess Palace and Buckingham Palace detachments. The New Guard, who during the course of the ceremony become The Queens Guard, march to Buckingham Palace from Wellington Barracks with musical accompaniment.

Check website for confirmed dates and times.
feed.shortDescription: Changing the Guard at Buckingham Palace encompasses colourful spectacle and British pageantry.

feed.title: Underbelly Festival
feed.address: Belvedere Road Coach Park London SE1 8XX
feed.price: Vast majority of tickets are under £20 but check website for actual prices.
feed.description: Underbelly festival will be back again for its 11th year on the south bank. Open from April until the end of September, Underbelly Festival Southbank brings the best in live circus, comedy, cabaret and family entertainment to the heart of London. They have an amazing line-up of shows in an amazing city-centre, pop-up festival world. You can enjoy international street food, after work drinks in one of London's largest outdoor bars and a true festival atmosphere on the banks of the Thames.

feed.title: Manga
feed.address: Great Russell Street, Bankside, London WC1B 3DG
feed.openingTime: Open daily 10am to 5.30pm and late Fri 10am to 8.30pm. Last entry is 80 mins before closing
feed.transport: Tottenham Court Road, Russell Square, Holborn
feed.station: Tottenham Court Road, Russell Square, Holborn
feed.bus: 1, 8, 19, 25, 38, 55, 98, 242 (New Oxford Street), 4, 24, 29, 73, 134, 390(Tottenham Court Road), 59, 68, X68, 91, 168, 188(Southampton Row)
feed.price: Adults £19.50, under 16s free 2 for 1 tickets for students on Fridays
feed.description: A recreation of the oldest surviving manga bookshop in Tokyo comes to the British Museum as it stages the largest exhibition of manga ever to take place outside of Japan. Literally meaning pictures run riot this narrative art form has crossed over into other forms of cultural expression, including cosplay dressing up. Contemporary manga and digital anime are linked to their historic roots as Manga gives us a chance to see the origins of modern Japanese cartoons and  spoiler alert  theyre older than you think. The Handscrolls of Frolicking Animals (Choju giga), for example, dating back to 1200 AD, is considered by some to be the foundation of modern manga. Showing bestselling books from the 1970s, anime and gaming, the exhibition shows how manga has become a multimedia global phenomenon.

feed.title: Buckingham Palace State Rooms
feed.address: Buckingham Palace Road, Westminster, London SW1A 1AA
feed.openingTime: 9.30am to 7.30pm (20 Jul to 31 Aug), 9.30am-6.30pm (1 to 29 Sep)
feed.description: Every summer inquisitive visitors get the chance to look around Buckingham Palace and admire the grand State Rooms used by heads of state at the Summer Opening. See the nineteen State Rooms which are still used by the Royal Family to receive and entertain guests on state and ceremonial occasions. Decorated in lavish fashion, they include paintings by Rembrandt, Rubens and Canaletto, Sevres porcelain and some of the finest English and French furniture in the world. There are also some exquisite royal gifts, including Faberge Eggs, on display. This is a fascinating opportunity to admire the taste - often wonderful, sometimes comically bad - of Britain's monarchy.

feed.title: Pride 2019
feed.description: The Mayor of London will be supporting Pride in London celebrations on Saturday 6 July. The parade route starts from Portland Place finishing in Whitehall. Trafalgar Square will host a stage with live entertainment and a number of food, drink, information and community stalls. This year there will also be entertainment and events in the following areas, Soho, Dean Street, Golden Square, Leicester Square

feed.title: London Anime and Gaming Con
feed.address: Rocket Complex, 166-220 Holloway Rd, London N7 8DB
feed.openingTime: 10:30am (for prepaid), 11am for on the door. Tickets are available on the door. Friday Entry is Midday.
feed.price: Full Three Days £29 or from £9 a day.
feed.description: Over 100 Activities, stage events, panels, parties, performaces and many guests. Top voice actors from  your favourite anime, anime viewing room, manga artists, anime and geek exhibitors and Live J-pop Anime themed performers. Cosplay Competitions and top prizes, talks and workshops. A massive line up of RPG and board gaming. Video Gaming from animeleague does go 8 bit, retro game challenge, The Big gaming quiz with more to be revealed from talks with top youtube gaming guests and musicians and lots more.

feed.title: Hyper Japan
feed.address: Olympia London Hammersmith Road, Kensington, London W14 8UX
feed.description: Celebrating 10 Years of HYPER JAPAN HYPER JAPAN, it began in 2010 at the Old Truman Brewery over near Brick Lane. Taking over the upper level of the parking lot, it featured 20 or so booths with a small but incredibly passionate stage! Festival 2019 will return to Olympia London where we will be taking over the Olympia Grand and the Olympia West. In the Olympia Grand, you will find all your favourite stands on the Ground floor, divided into the Asakusa Culture Zone, the Akihabara Game and Anime Zone, and the Harajuku Kawaii Fashion Zone.
